I would rather to watch a concert than to watch this. Not worth the time and money. The Visual Effect and CGI is indeed great, but the song is just too much. The writers just magically cramped the movie so it fits 5-6 songs (literally a single album) in one movie. And then, in the end, they put 2 more "sad theme" song to baited audience's emotional after crappy one hour. Yeah, it's right, they ended literally song movie (I prefer to called it like that rather musical movie), with more SONGS with DIFFERENT EMOTION. So, literally minutes ago we got energetic happy song, andthen next we got furious rage song, and lastly we got "forced" sad song. My ear and brain is so confused, that I can't even laugh at 'marvel-like' jokes/comedy scene in-between songs.

It is also my fault, I didn't expect it to be song movie or musical movie or whatever. With the title "RED" - which I think about Red Hair Pirate, and it's not - and the gimmick "Shanks' daughter", I was expected to see more of Shanks' crew fight (they literally who saved the movie), but unluckily it didn't happen (it also makes me learn to read the synopsis carefully before watch any movies).

At the middle of 'awkwardly sitting in the dark' place for 2 hours-long most awaited movie, I realized, "Yup, this movie is not for me."

My first review ever, and it had to be One Piece Film Red. Just want to clarify some things before you continue: 1- I'm the biggest fan of Ado. As a J-pop enjoyer, listening to her songs since 2021 made my life less hard sometimes. 2- Even tho I read the manga, I'm not a fanatic one piece fan, and I literally just watced the movie because Ado was singing. 3- This is gonna be so partial and not rational at all, but since it was a special movie (I was almost crying everytime Ado was singing bc holy smokes she rocks) I really wanted to write this. So, aboutthe movie, I saw a lot of bad reviews about it. About how Uta is a bad character, about it had too many songs in it and lastly, "if I wanted to watch an idol movie, I would be watching an idol movie". to be fair with you, it's a bit exaggerated, the songs were the best part (def not partial at all) and yes, there are people that are watching bc it has music involved. Overall, there were some inconsistency in the story but the animation was pretty enjoyable and last fight gave me goosebumps

For other people, since 90% of them are shounen fans and only want to see fights, I'm sure there will be lots of ppl that liked, but a lot more that didnt.


Rate:
Story - doesnt matter
Animation - doesnt matter
Music - 10000000000000000/10
Characters - doesnt matter
Enjoyment - 10/10 (for me ofc)
Overall rating - 10/10 (not bc its "masterpiece" like MAL says, but its based on how I have feelings for this movie)

Summary: Honestly, I'm dissappointed. If it wasn't connected to One Piece, I'd give it a 7/10 as it was a good Movie in itself. Since it has basically no connections to the main series though, it's nothing but a somewhat long Spin-Off OVA or Filler Episode. If you enjoy music stuff in Movies, you may enjoy this one, if not, save yourself the time and skip it - you are not missing out on anything important. A few more Details: As for the content... I guess Animations where solid and enjoyable - Some of the Music was decent too. Storywise, it didnt add anything that we may need inthe main story - classic side story. The MC for this also feels rather plain and forgettable except for the visual design - no deep thoughts or meaning behind anything. Any other character may as well be replaced with something generic and the plot would still work as is.

So basically, it's a good "Movie" but not a good "One Piece Movie" - I really expected something more interesting that connects to the main story.

The movie picks up after episodes 1029–1030, introducing Uta as the central character. If you're thinking of watching the French dub... honestly, don't. I made that mistake and it really messed up the experience for me. The singing voice for Uta in the French version just doesn't work. The songs sound off, sometimes even out of tune, and the voice feels totally disconnected from the character. It was hard to enjoy the film with that in the background. On the other hand, the voice actress for Uta's spoken lines is clearly a pro. Her performance is way better and actually pleasant to listen to. It really showshow singing and voice acting are two separate skills, and in this case, the difference is obvious. Probably why they didn’t use the same person for both.
Story-wise, it's not bad. And it's always cool to see the One Piece crew in different outfits.

Megumi Ishitani’s Cinematic Masterpiece I was left with chills in almost every scene, and I couldn’t be happier with how it turned out. The blend of emotion, action, and storytelling was absolutely beautiful, reminding me of exactly why I love this series so much. The marines, in particular, stood out for me. The reanimation of Marineford was visually stunning, and seeing Oars Jr. in that heartbreaking moment hit hard. The Straw Hats brought their signature humor, adding a refreshing contrast to the heavier themes. What really struck me was how we were treated to a brief but powerful revisit of the Marineford war, a pivotal arc forany fan. One of the standout moments for me was when a marine, initially about to abandon his brother, saw Luffy's relentless determination to save Ace and turned back to help. That shift in resolve, inspired by Luffy's sheer will, was truly touching and beautifully handled.

Megumi Ishitani’s direction felt like a love letter to the fans, a reminder of the series' emotional depth and epic scale. This episode was a much-needed refresh, and I absolutely loved every minute of it.

Honestly, what an episode!  One Piece Fan Letter showcased the feeling of yearning to meet the people you admired so much and how events in life can change what we believe in. Most importantly, this episode is a celebration of the 25th anniversary of One Piece.  The animation, overall story, directing, music, and other aspects are really well made, and you can see it through the episode itself. With the same quality as the continuous Egghead arc in the anime (though it is on break, upon writing this review), this episode goes hard! I mean, really hard!  I honestly relate to the characters in the episode, especially thegirl main character. The yearning and wanting to express how much you admire that person through a letter and letting them know about it despite the danger and challenges it comes with is dedication and fulfilling in the end. 

While watching the episode, I ended up cheering for the girl to meet the person she admires (of course no spoilers, but anyways). 

Overall, One Piece Fan Letter (in my opinion) is a touching and well-made episode.

This is the best episode I've ever seen in my life. I don't think anything will ever top this, at least for a very long time. Everything about it was perfection and it perfectly captures the soul of what One Piece is. In a single 24 minute episode it made me care for characters I've never seen until today and these characters and their stories have completely changed my perspective on the series as a whole. We never think about the lives of the average citizen or marine while watching/reading One Piece, it really shows us that these characters have lives, family's, friends people theylove and care for too. The perspective of the Marine soldiers in war broke me into pieces. Don't want to say too much but this is a Masterpiece, and if you haven't seen One Piece I beg of you do to so, it will change your life.

This is simply one of the best anime works ever made and the director Megumi Ishitani is guilty of it. First of all, in order to fully understand this episode and being able to appreciate all its details, it is needed to watch/read until the "Return to Sabaody" arc (included), since the whole plot is set in this framework of events. All the stories that appear in the episode are told from the very own perspective of the characters that participate in it. All this characters are normal persons (at least they are far away from the usual extravagant characters that Eiichiro Oda has all of usaccustomed to) and all of them are fans of the Straw Hats. This is what it makes them feel really special and very close, they are truly in tune with the wonders and amazing things the Crew has accomplished and are also inspired by them, making Megumi Ishitani suceed in connecting with the spectator, almost to the point of feeling to be part of the story.

Regarding the visual part, the animation is impeccable. The scenes are incredibly fluid and the drawing style is precious. But the best point of the visuals is the amazing visual language that Ishitani always brings into the episodes she directs, specially regarding the ilumination effects and light symbolisms full of meaningful messages without saying a single word. Here, we could talk about, for example: on how the girl is positioned in the dark when hope is fainting and how the light comes back when hope arises again; or how she is seen behind metal bars when she wants to be free and claiming liberty.

Furthermore, there are tons of details to pay attention to, many of the main events of the episode are consequence of side and secondary actions of the crew members that one could not even imagine when seeing the original series for the first time. To state a few examples: the concert Brook gives in Sabaody originates huge crowds of people that make the little girl impossible to keep moving forward; the iconic scene of Rayleigh stoping the marines from pursuing Luffy is a big deal for the marines of this story; the enormous bugs and insects that Usopp bringed are incredible menaces for the protagonists; it also appears the comical scene of the World Government secret agents catching the fake Chopper, crashing with the girl and making her stumbling; and many more.

In few words, this episode tells the stories of fans of the Straw Hats, that, as well as the spectator, admire the crew. The great amount of feelings and emotions this episode awakens is what it makes it a "must see" for every One Piece fan.

So much joy packed into 24 minutes. I was grinning ear to ear throughout. It shouldn't be hard to believe that One Piece can grace us with a one-off special that hits this hard, but it still blew me away. The fanservice was perfectly timed and didn't overstay its welcome, the perspective shifts were awesome and recontextualized a lot of what happened during two pivotal arcs without changing them, the new characters were a joy to watch, and yes, the animation was incredible (checks the team behind it... oh yeah, no wonder - same director behind Where the Wind Blows and instrumental in OP26). Other studiosand directors, take notes: this is how you do it.

This is a kind of cute little short set just before the Fishman's Island arc in One Piece. It was an interesting exploration into world building and seeing how the Strawhats might function as celebrities in their world. I liked how it also illustrated how difficult it must be to live in a town that is a Marine outpost. I would definitely watch more of these little world building special episodes. If you like One Piece, then you'll likely like this. Admittedly I wish that it could have dug a little deeper but it was decent for what it was.

Honestly one of the BEST episodes in all of One Piece. Getting to see just how inspirational all of the Strawhats are-not just Luffy-on a personal level, as well as a great mix of humour (Sanji getting mad no one was talking about him xd) but also some surprisingly deep moments I didn’t expect, all animated and directed absolutely beautifully. A fantastic range of characters, all of whom felt really human-like, something very impressive for a 25ish minute episode! Also, on a side note, the young girl may be the most relatable character of all time now because I would act the exact same wayif I heard I had the chance to meet Nami.
Overall, incredible. One Piece fans stay winning!!

The best episode of One Piece?? The animation was stunning from the first second to the last! The level of detail in each frame was astounding, with every single one possessing the beauty to serve as a standalone wallpaper.👌 The art style reminded me a lot of the scene in episode 1015 where Yamato hears Roger and Luffy's dream🔥 Witnessing the Marineford battle through the eyes of an ordinary marine was a powerful experience. The chaos of relentless explosions and the marines' inability to do anything about it was quite cool to see. I actually want this type of filler episode to be more common, if they could make onfor every arc that would be perfect!
WOW WOW WOW WOW is all i got to say👍

''every little thing is changing my life little by little.'' One piece fan letter is without a shadow of a doubt a genuine masterpiece, and I don't say that lightly. I have been a one piece fans since I was 14, I remember reading syrup village in class as my friends urged me to keep reading. I fell in love with One Piece very quickly and since then it has been a monumental thing in my life and after watching this I truly think it always will. This is a love letter to One Piece fans, and Megumi Ishitani was the perfect person to direct this. Ishitani is apowerhouse and in recent years has brought us some of the most mesmerizingly beautiful animation I've ever seen through her sequences and direction on episodes of the One Piece anime and she doesn't disappoint here. The animation is beautiful with a stacked animation staff on clear display.

The story is also something that caught me off guard, it's a story about the Straw Hats influence on every day people in the One Piece world and it's placed around the Return to Sabaody arc and Marineford arc. 

It's so heartfelt in a way I never thought a One Piece spin off could pull off and I was crying by the end and my friend who also watched this with me cried as-well, I have never seen him cry before this.

One Piece is a powerful series and if you have any amount of love for it, watch Fan Letter. You will fall in love with One Piece all over again.

俺は海賊王になる!!!

10/10

Megumi Ishitani blessed us with another top-tier directing technique. After following One Piece for years, seeing another side of the story is just so beautiful. We are really put in other character's shoes on how they perceived the One Piece world and the Straw Hat Pirates. Seeing Luffy's development, Zoro and Sanji debate (LOL), and other characters in this point of view brings some sort of happiness as a fan. Not to mention the animation, cinematography, and all the other techniques used in this special episode is just like seeing episode 1015 for the first time again. These techniques make me relate to how thesenormal people think about the Great Pirates Era. It shed a tear of happiness from my eyes.

Definitely recommended, especially if you've been following One Piece for so long!!

Do you recall ever getting so invested in a few characters in a first episode that it felt like they were around for an entire series? In anything? No, right? Well, think again; In just a few minutes this episode manages to encapulate the magnitude of the One Piece world, which is so big, that doing so feels impossible, at least, before meeting this masterpiece. Beatifully using the scope of every day people that are, just like us, admirers from afar of this crew, even though they live in the same world, the creaters manage to in a very short 20 minutes; Introduce acharacter, her motives, and givie a fulfilling end to her journey without making it feel rushed at all, and, that, with a gorgeous animation. No words. Honestly, even if you're not a One Piece fan,
 
Watch it.









Set sail!

(This story took place in “Return to Sabaody Arc” Ep 522) One Piece Fan Letter is a piece of tribute to the fans of the series 25th anniversary. Crafted in such fashion that celebrates both fans and its long-running volume by tying us viewers in a little story from the perspective of an ordinary side character, that just particularly deepened One Piece world beyond fiction. This little tale wasn’t just deep and well executed, but also woven a filler event into its main storyline that actually came out as a crucial turning point in the story. The Straw Hats impacted the whole world, but now theworld impacted One Piece storyline in an extent you haven’t seen much of anywhere. By tying the fans and the viewers of the series like they are actually part of the story. They are present in the journey of both the Straw Hats and in the series success. 

The way they gave characters personalities and topics to debate on the Straw Hats crew members based on the fans of the series made One Piece already huge world even wider. As it ultimately just brake down the boundaries between fiction and reality. By giving characters fannish-stereotypes and connections to helping the Straw Hats, admiring or hating them. It was all there and it was beautiful, it was emotional. 

Everyone is part of the puzzle, everyone is holding a piece of the journey. As the true OG viewers are now invested 25 years of their lives into this fiction, is really a recognition saying; They see us. They acknowledged the fans in such an incredible storytelling, that I have never seen anywhere else before. It definitely could be the best episode of 2024, but I could go even further to say this might just be the greatest episode of all times.

It was truly exceptional. Definitely a piece of work that made me moved, even though I only watching the show since 2023. 

Personally, I really loved this type of animation they chose to go with. This loosely and curvy design as it gives you the feeling of freedom, the freedom of art. Which One Piece is all about and although it’s not fancy or super detailed, there wasn’t any static frame, it always had movements and colorful animations, which was also hand drawn by the way. 

So hats off to all the people who have worked on this project and may I address my highest respect to Toei Animation Studio for their 25 years of dedication and pure excellence. 

As an anime fan, you have to acknowledge greatness and this was: Marvelous

Final Score: 9/10 ⭐️

Thank you for reading!

I hate that I'm a One Piece fan. The big arcs, the big backstories, the characters. There's always something that destroys me with One Piece, and I thought this was just a simple little thing. A fun episode, with great animation, and a great little plot. Like a short-film about the world, but even this little thing can get me crying. 20 minutes, that's all it took. We don't follow the original crew on this one, but the public perception on their biggest moment. Instead of a grand fight, or a grand moment, we just get people, and how from their simple, and outside outlooktheir lives changed. There's something about Luffy, a hotheaded kid, with an earnest desire to save the ones he loves against unsurmountable odds, which inspired a soldier, to save his brother. Something in Nami, a smart, non-powered human, changing the world with pure wit and tools, which inspires a little girl to change the world. 

Each character has that little something, which echoes throughout the world. Their efforts aren't meaningless, their efforts change lives, and motivate those around them. It makes their story not only being important to us, but important for the world around them. They save lives, not only with the actions they take, but with those who look at such actions. 

It's so fresh, seeing a positive chain reaction of pure hope. We always get the cycle of violence, the cycle of sadness, and despair. Not many times we get something so hopeful, that makes the world a better place by simply happening. It made me cry not from the tragedy of it all but from happiness. Not a good deal of anime cause that, and One Piece can certainly focus a lot more on the tragedy, but that's exactly what makes this so perfect. 

So many tragedies, so much horror in that particular world. For once, we get the glimmer of hope. These people, small, or big, old or young, all of them can change the world, piece by piece, action by action.

Brilliant animation, brilliant characters, and an unmatched fast pacing that tells everything so fast, and so effectively. It was perfect. A perfect piece of One Piece. 

10/10. We need more overwhelmingly happy moments like this.

The special episodes of this anime are very touching, as a nakama who watches always spotlight on the main character, you are invited to imagine the side character's story. very simple packaging but very warm. this is my review as a common viewer. While this may be a side story to the main narrative, the anime has a strong emotional appeal. It highlights the sense of friendship, inspiration, and dreams that are at the core of One Piece. While it doesn't provide a major plot that relates to the main storyline, “Fan Letter” manages to provide reflective moments for viewers who have followed the adventures ofthe Straw Hats over the years.

Overall, One Piece: Fan Letter presents high-quality graphics with a heartfelt story, making it the perfect offering for longtime fans looking for a more personalized experience in the world of One Piece.

genuinely so good and a must watch for a longtime one piece fan, chronicles like a slice of life from right before they reunite in the timeskip and really reminds you about all the positive perspectives towards the straw hats (from the navy, from the young girl) that the paramount war amplified for everybody. from very early on we have been reminded how even their 'enemies' can be their biggest supporters, and that there is a greater moral good than just being on the side of black and white. i think it's hard to remember that when it's not said out loud, and this fanletter really captures raw perspectives we otherwise don't get because we are always seeing things from the straw hats' pov. the straw hats are so loved and this was truly a fan letter to one piece itself. the ending theme was so nostalgic - really love how it fully throws us back to the timeskip arc with the same theme song redone!

I'm genuinely surprised by the quality of this One Piece's special episode. The animation, and characters designs are all on point. Props to Toei Animation. A refreshingly humane look at the wonderful world of One Piece, in this episode, you get to look at the 'normal' people that live there. What are their feelings and thoughts on the 'larger than life' Straw Hat? How to live in the world of super human when you're just everyday ordinary folks? Find out yourself since the special is only 25 mins long. I would love a series out of this concept. I love One Piece and I welcome thisaddition to one of the greatest shows of all time.

It's abundantly clear that pure heart and soul went into this project. Fantastic, impactful, and such a fresh perspective in the ridiculous world of One Piece through incredibly expressive animation. Fans of One Piece and animation will appreciate this special. In the past, Toei animation has not had the best reputation when it came to producing anime, especially when it comes to One Piece. I don't blame their dip in quality after the time skip. As an animator and artist myself, I fully understand that what they're doing to produce a 20 minute weekly series of animation is quite literally a miracle. Any viewer backduring the airing of Dressrosa arc of One Piece would most likely by turned off from the anime for years due to the incredibly slow pacing and cheap animation tricks. However, in these past few years I have seen tremendous increase in the quality of work that is honestly above and beyond what any fan of One Piece could have believed. Whatever they changed about their production, it has improved everything for the One Piece anime.

I am not one for "glazing" only specific people of a production because in reality it is a team effort that makes the project possible. However, it is undeniable that Megumi Ishitani is a tremendous director, evident by the cinematography and visual, and deserves all of the praise that is coming her way.

One Piece Fan Letter is a love letter not just to the characters and the world of One Piece, but also to the fans who have stuck with the franchise for all of these years.

Thank you, Toei.

7/10 ~ how did I get here So I dont one piece really, and this just auto played after I finished watching Dandadan, but I had no idea what I was watching but said fuck it, its only 24 minutes. And my god, this was a fantastic little piece here, im sure this would hit much harder if I truly understood what was going on during this little film. I did not know the events they were referring to but I could follow it all well enough. This felt like one of those pre-film Pixar shorts like the Oldman playing chess or w.e, and it waspretty refreshing to just sit back and watch the gorgeous animation with a pretty nice conclusion. 

If I do ever make the journey and do actually watch Once Piece in its entirety im sure ill come back and re-appreciate this one.

A New Standard of Excellence for the 23-Minute Format “Nami-san, you're my hope. In this world where power is everything, even if I get hurt and trampled on, I still want to struggle, run, and live as freely as I can. I came to think that way thanks to you.” One Piece is a fictional world that faces many of the same issues that ours does: corrupted government, revision of history, censorship, unchecked greed, political unrest, poverty, sickness, and starvation. Fan Letter explores the individuals who inhabit that world, affected by its follies. What gives them hope? What gives them courage? What gives them empowerment? Just likeus, in the world where One Piece is not reality, but a story, it is their heroes. In Fan Letter, I see an illustration of those like you and me — like our brothers, mothers, friends, and neighbors. Through the eyes of characters pushed around in a corrupt, hurting world, I find empowerment, hope, and the courage to keep living in my own corrupt, hurting world. That is the power of storytelling. That is the power of Fan Letter.

Megumi Ishitani is a directing marvel — peerless in her craft as far as I am concerned. I have watched Fan Letter three times now, reached an emotional catharsis I can only describe as nirvana, and noticed new details which add to that experience each time. For those overwhelmed by the pace and depth of Fan Letter, rewatching is its own reward. You will get something new out of it every time, your love for One Piece renewed. The animation and artwork itself powers the story to its fullest potential, adding to the visual depth and joy of a story which could be moving all on its own. I would be remiss not to mention the abject artfulness of the story on top of its narrative, but that could be a review all on its own.

The ultimate recommendation I have for those interested in watching (or re-watching) is to keep in mind two meanings of “fan” and “One Piece”: what they mean in the story, and what they mean to us as fans of the show. Beautifully illustrated as puzzle pieces, the characters using their “one piece” to complete an unseen puzzle. These serve as “ah-ha” moments for the characters involved; a moment where their place in the world comes into crystal clear perspective as an action — there is something they can do or become to make the world a better place. Incidentally, these are actions which aid the Straw Hats in their journey. The implication is that there is power in the small acts of good we do — the ripple effects of self-actualization and standing up for brief moments of goodness and bravery add up to the wave which is the dawn of a New Era of peace and prosperity in their world.

The narrative encourages us to consider — what is our “one piece”? Have you experienced that moment yet, or will you be encouraged to look at your life with new eyes, eager to discover it? Will you, like me, feel overwhelmed with gratitude for stories like One Piece, that encourage us to be better humans in our own world each day? It is my deepest wish for everyone to experience the power of this piece of media, and find their own power within it as well.

* Made me emotional, happy and terrified of the one piece world grandeur. i can relate to the problems experienced by these side character and how small and powerless they are in the grand scheme of things just like in real world. 10/10 animation 10/10 story telling 1/10 cause i want 9 more episodes of this greatness. If you are a person who is interested in world building and every minor detail you'll love this whole series and this special fan letter. Btw i think the change in artstyle actually really complements the show. One Piece: fan letter is a masterpiece of world-building, storytelling, and animation. The episode is full ofemotion, happiness, and terror, as we are introduced to the vast and dangerous world of One Piece. The side characters in this episode are all relatable and sympathetic, and we can't help but feel for them as they struggle to survive in a world that is so much larger and more powerful than they are.

The animation in this episode is simply stunning. Every detail is perfectly rendered, and the action sequences are both thrilling and visually impressive. The storytelling is also top-notch. The episode is paced perfectly, and the plot is both complex and engaging.

However, there is one major flaw with this episode: it is too short! At only one hour long, the episode feels like it is just getting started when it is over. I would have loved to see at least nine more episodes of this greatness.

If you are a person who is interested in world-building and every minor detail, you will love this whole series and this special fan letter. The change in art style actually really complements the show.

Overall, One Piece: fan letter is a must-watch for any fan of anime or storytelling. It is a truly special episode that will leave you wanting more.

Absolute peak storytelling and animation. If you are a fan of One Piece then consider this an absolute must watch. It was heartwarming and heartbreaking at the same time. Truly the world of One Piece is full of boundless potential to tell deep stories even in shorter formats like this. This simple and straight forward story takes you deep into the lowly commons of Sabaody Archipeligo on the day the Straw Hats reunite after their 2 year break from the perspective of a downtrodden young girl who simply wants to express her appreciation for the courage given to her by Nami.

I literally made a MAL account and waited a week to write a review about how amazing this special episode was. I was expecting NOTHING from the episode but now, I'd sell my soul for a spin-off series focusing on normal citizens in the world of One Piece. The episode itself was a roller coaster ride. It's funny one moment, emotional in another. Despite the short screen time of the characters, it was surprisingly easy to grow attached to them by the end of the episode. They were all very well written despite the short runtime. Rewatched it few times the week it was released.Genuinely wished it was an hour long. It's just so genuinely beautiful and I can't describe it any other way.

The animation also suits the overall whimsical aspect of One Piece. You can tell that the episode was made with a lot of care and consideration both towards the fans and One Piece itself. Long-time fans would definitely enjoy this episode. Wouldn't recommend this to anyone who only watches One Piece for the sake of it or just for the action.

The main things that this special entails is overall good animation, callbacks, and iconic moments from One piece plus some cute moments. As to why the animation is not perfect is due to some ugly still shots of the marines but overall the animation is smooth and looks fairy tail like and easy on the eyes. This special really highlights how other characters in One Piece sees the main crew and other great figures in the One piece world as well and why they Admire them, there are different reasons for different individuals as well which makes it more interesting and nuanced. And the twomain characters who has the most love put in them are likeable and enjoyable to watch as well because they contrast well with one being a naive girl and one being a war torn Marine so you do not have to have watched One piece before to enjoy this experience. 
However because of this, the episode splits to too many different perspectives which makes most of the characters existence about glazing someone else instead of developing their own story or moments. It is not all that bad though because the characters that we follow the most reinforces their own character by taking inspiration from notable characters of One piece. so the director made the best out of this problem. It still does not mean I would enjoy the story more than a story that focuses on characters who develop from their own experiences and connections instead of them having their character being about only being a "x" fan. Especially when the run time only is 24 minutes, and yes the purpose of the episode is to celebrate one piece and its cast. But it actually makes or breaks the story and is why there is so much disparity between One piece fans and bystanders who watched the special, because One piece fans love the glazing, and some bystanders hate it because they have not grown to like the ones being glazed. Not as if its the entire reason behind the disparity but it is a big part since it also spreads out the potential scenes for characters to have their own agency in the plot.
 In contrast, it is a lot more clear that the OST is as good as it has always been, the music both new and old fits the scenes very well. Especially the new music tracks that was made for the brothers and for the finale for the atmosphere. By the way the finale was amazing for what it was and really tied this mini story together by using what we know about the plot and the characters with the ost blasting full swing. 

 So it was a pleasant experience overall, I do not advice watching this if you hate One piece but if you are neutral or like One piece it is a good to great watch.

This was SUCH an incredible little one-off idea. Just a single episode that showcases various no-name background characters within the world of One Piece and how the Straw Hat Pirates have indirectly influenced their lives, despite not being pirates or having any actual connections or relationships with any of them. Just like how Detective Pikachu is a detective movie that just so happens to take place within the world of Pokemon, Fan Letter is a story within the One Piece world, but has absolutely nothing to do with One Piece or pirates or the great, overarching narrative as a whole, really. Which I REALLY, reallyloved! I'd be up for an entire show with this concept, despite how much I hope Oda retires and gets 1000 years of sleep that he so desperately deserves and needs once One Piece is finally finished. I also love that they just went with an ENTIRELY different art style for this one, just for funsies! It's all so bouncy and vibrant and looks ABSOLUTELY NOTHING like One Piece, which just works in its favor in trying to be a completely detached side story. I say "completely detached" but this story does still take place within a very specific moment in One Piece that you DEFINITELY shouldn't spoil for yourself by watching this short. It's a shame that I can't just recommend it to anyone unless they've seen the first 520 or so episodes of One Piece beforehand, but them's the breaks. This was just a really fun surprise that I didn't see coming and just reminded me of everything I love about One Piece, while also getting a perspective on why other people may love it in ways that even I've never thought about, before. Absolutely watch this if you're caught up. Or at least at the halfway point.

9.5/10

I cant describe how much of a masterpiece this felt like . just seeing The Pov of Normal people in Marineford arc , Normal marines , not MC or anything , and that legendary animation, PEAK, THIS IS PEAK, we get a 6 month break , and not only a week passed by and we get this release , No amount of words can describe how this EP made me feel, it gave me one hell of a de ja vu, reminded me of my Love for one piece, why this show stuck with me , it brought back So much memories, Thank you for this incredible  adaptation , Its beyond amazing.

A very well-rounded special anime episode that is not only considered canon but also incorporates essential elements from One Piece. It’s the first new anime content I’ve seen from One Piece in a while since the Gear 5 episode. (Sorry, I’m primarily a manga reader so I haven’t done my best to stay up to date with the anime.) Animation is great—it’s the first one in a while that feels fresh, and whatever changes occurred in the Egghead arc really stand out. I appreciate how fluid the animation is and how much more detail they’ve added, even with the relatively simple art style with expressionsand movements remain smooth and impressive. Story is very easy to understand, a girl inspired by Nami is trying to send her letter, and the expansion on the Navy soldiers from Marineford adds a nice touch. I wish that part had been given more time. The episode takes place just before the Straw Hats reunite at Sabaody after the time skip, setting the stage for their journey together after two years. This timing makes sense, as it seems to set up the polished Fish-Man Island arc, which will follow soon. This special episode feels complete because it captures the comedic essence of One Piecee, a nostalgic reminder of how fun the series was before the story shifted to the final war with its more serious tone, OST during Luffy’s jump to punch down the cloned Kuma was also excellent, the way One Piece mixes lighthearted humor with deeply emotional moments is captured perfectly in this episode and seeing iconic characters return for this fan letter story adds even more charm. The “Fan Letter” feels like a heartfelt love letter to the fans, expressing gratitude for their continued support and appreciation by telling this small but meaningful story. 

I genuinely loved it. If it had been longer and made into a full movie, I probably would’ve given it a perfect 10 but whatever, I highly recommend this episode to any One Piece fan.

I loved it. The episode was imbued with so much joy and passion for this story that means so much to so many. We got to really see how much the straw hats mean to the people of that world the same way they mean an incredible amount to us; I was overwhelmed with such a loving warmth. So much of what makes One Piece fantastic is seeing how the characters change the world around them, usually on a massive scale. Getting to zero in on a handful of characters expressing how the straw hats affected them was such a tender sentiment to give us.I don’t know about anyone’s else, but in a way it was like getting to experience one piece for the first time and fall in love all over again. One piece has touched the hearts of so many people and getting to see that love put clearly on display speak volumes to the impact One Piece and its characters have hand on so many. I’m extremely grateful we got something like this especially with One Pieces end drawing closer and closer. I think a lot of people are going to feel like a part of themselves is gone after that happens. This will be a great episode to return to when one piece concludes, to remind us to keep our chins up just like the like Luffy and his crew would. Thank you Tomohito Ohsaki.

And to all the people commenting on the art, stick to Full Metal Alchemist and Jujutsu Kaisen your understanding of “good art” is clearly skewed

This is a single special episode, this will obviously over-inflate it's MAL scoring compared to whole series since easier to make a single episode a masterpiece, especially when based around 10/10 manga. This episode is amazing for both fans, and those that have never seen One Piece. Those that hate One Piece for some reason will of course not like this. The animation here is very different to the series and does great. It does not conflict with the series at all and let's use see the perspective of the people (fans) of One Piece that you'll never see otherwise. Animation/Art 10/10 Sound (I can't rate since don'tremember/didn't pay attention, so likely AT LEAST 8/10)
Story 10/10
Pacing 9/10
Uniqueness 10/10
Characters 8/10 (skewed down DRASTICALLY by character(s) I hated)
Continuity 10/10

Personally I was getting emotional/tears of happiness, until mid-way point that triggered my PTSD from multiple personal experiences so had to pause and cry/scream, then the rest of the episode was emotions/tears of happiness again with a brief sad moment.

I HIGHLY recommend for One Piece and non-One Piece viewers. Ichi Ni Sunshine Yon WE GO!

What a fantastic surprise, the episode just dropped out of the blue and came with perfect animation. As just a special episode I wasnt expecting this story to be so emotional. I unexpectedly got so engrossed with these characters very fast, especially the marine brothers. Also the reanimation of luffy using 2nd Gear to one shot that Pacifista was crazy. I would love to see more episodes of the One Piece World from a different point of view rather than the straw hat's. The director Megumi Ishitani really deserves and award for this, like she directed this and ep 1015?? She needs to do more episodes Also makinga burner acc to hate on this master piece is shamefull.

Although I'm recommending this special episode, this is not the case for non-fans. This is basically showing events on Sabaody from a fan perspective, that's why non-fans are baffled by its high score while fans are just having one of the best experience ever. That noted, what a ride was this. Had me with a big smile for most of the episode, reliving some of the most memorable events on OP and showing from another perspective, all of that with proper pacing and quality. It gives a movie feeling since we have quality and a bit of non-canonical events filled with light hearted moments, but ithas a regular episode length.

Like I said in the intro, it shows things from fans perspectives, some new characters that are fans of specific characters, like Nami or Brooke, have an opportunity of seeing the crew reuniting in Sabaody and why they like them so much. I won't spoil details, but it's like imagining yourself having this opportunity and going out of your way to try to catch at least a glimpse of them, discussing why your favorite character is the best etc

Honestly a great little piece of fanfare that looks at a more grim version of the marineford war. You can feel that the production team put in so much love for this little project. The art style is much prettier than the typical one piece anime episode. The story is short and sweet, but has great emotional moment's for the amount of time it gets to spend with the little girl character. If you're a fan of One Piece, you will love this. If you haven't watched or read one piece, I'm not so sure that you will enjoy this as much, but it might stilltug at your heartstrings a little at some parts.

This One Piece anime 25th anniversary special is about the normal people who live in the One Piece world and how their lives have been affected by the ongoing adventures of the Straw Hat Pirates. The animation in this special is done entirely in an absolutely gorgeous style. Director Megumi Ishitani has a way of capturing the essence of One Piece using very simple shapes and flat colouring, but it oozes so much charm and character. It borders on absurdist at points, prioritising the feeling that each scene and character should give you over what it actually looks like. I'd argue that the special is worthwatching on it's own even if you've never watched One Piece before. The animation is *that* good (you may find it difficult to follow what's happening though).

There's so much sincerity to the narrative. The way these characters look up to the Straw Hat Pirates mirrors the fandom for the One Piece series in the real world. With a show that's gone on for as long as One Piece has, it feels like this special was made largely by a crew who themselves grew up with One Piece and want to express the passion they have for it that allowed them to become artists today. 

I absolutely love this special. It's simple, but it's emotionally honest to a fault, and that's what I love about this series so much. The perfect way to celebrate 25 years.

I Just Watched It!!!! WHAT THE HELLLLL was This EPISODE!!! 😭😭🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥 MEGUMI ISHITANI is The Absolute GOAT!!!🙌🔥 The ANIMATIONS!!!, ART STYLE!!!, Sound Designing, STORY!!!! {The Story was Unique & Nostalgic at the Same TIME!!} & The Characters {which inspite giving such a little screen time Holded so much Depth to themselves 💯} EVERYTHING was so Damn Perfect its INSANE!!!... Also Marineford Animations in MEGUMI ISHITANI's Style 😭🙌💯🔥🔥🔥 23 Minutes of Absolute Peakness! In Every Aspect!!10/10 Episode and its not even CANON 😭

I hope, if Possible they Make This Story and its Characters Canon to the Manga as This Story doesn't affect or change anything from the Main PLOT or Storyline.

Girl isn't really different from all of us. In a world where war is constant and everyone is powerful, what can we do as ordinary people to change it? What can we do to change OUR world? As an One Piece fan for almost 20 years something always felt missing for me since although the political message is there and we can resonate with a reasonable amount of the characters in the show, it lacked something to put me in their shoes. Then there's Girl. You'll cry with her tears of joy, you'll be frustrated with her, you'll vibrate with her, you'll go all over adventuresyou already loved but from a completely new perspective. All of it in mere 24 minutes.

Fan Letter embodies everything one love about One Piece and what makes it so outstanding for almost three decades. And the best of all, from your eyes, the eyes of someone that loves them as much as you do.

We, the One Piece fans, just keep on eating, to the point where you’d just feel bad for the other fandoms. Again, after a long period, Megumi Ishitani surprises us, along with Kisuke Mori with a timeless masterclass that feeds off an ancient and popular fantasy, what would it be like to be a normal citizen in the world of One Piece? One Piece Fan Letter is exactly what it would look like. Adventurous, larger than life, brutal, and depressing. An exaggerated interpretation of our own world. I feel like mentioning Ishitani’s name should have been enough to relay the weight and classiness of this masterpiece, butman, that does not do it justice. The direction, the animation, the auditions, the storyboarding, everything, the whole package is PEAK incarnate.

We go through the lenses of different characters through some of the events of Marineford and the day the Straw Hats reunited on The Sabaody Archipelago two years later, a few whimsical characters get tangled up in the whole thing and steam the spotlights along, a unique take on what many would call “filter”.

A very cartoony and bubbly art style was utilized, the same one used for opening 26 of the Anime and some parts of egghead, it fits Oda’s vision the most out of all other art styles used in the lifetime of the show, it makes you wonder if Wit’s The One Piece adaptation is not on similar grounds then we do not want it.

This was such a timeless short, one of those that leave a mark and you’d no longer the same person as before watching it, or at least, your view on One Piece will never remain the same. It’s a world that’s lived.

Overall: 10/10.

You know, i came into this expecting some mindless filler to satisfy my need for one piece... By the time the outro played, i deadass had a shitty grin on my face with a few tears on the verge of falling. As someone who's been watching one piece since elementary school, almost a decade ago, this special hit me hard. The animation was smooth and fluid, and the art style they used was perfect. The music also was integrated perfectly into the scenes. Megumi once again delivers her best for us fans to feast on. Not to mention this self contained story was touching andyet managed to elevate the existing story of one piece. Also the gags derived from how it represented one piece fans so perfectly were hilarious. It's a masterpiece.

This is a must watch for One Piece fans. The artstyle is pleasant and the animation is smooth. This special episode gives you an inside look on the lives of the "ordinary" people in the One Piece universe. People with no devil fruit powers or monstrous brute strength. This story lets you empathize with them as they try to survive in a dangerous world. We also see how the Strawhats influence and inspire these ordinary people just by being themselves. If you are a fan of One Piece, I highly recommend you to watch this. However, make sure you have watched or read One Pieceup until the very beginning of the Fishman Island arc before you watch this episode.

I just got back from my first ever Japan trip and crying while typing this after watching this special episode. One Piece really is a big part of my life now and I'm so haappy that this episode makes a representation of us fans who love the characters as if they're our own friends irl. We've seen them in their ups and downs and shared their struggles and happiness while rooting for them to reach their dreams -- it's just so magical. The road is long and the end is still nowhere to be found but I will never stop watching this show that is one ofthe reasons why I'm able to live freely today.

Have also completed my Strawhats crew figures from my Akihabara haul which makes this so special.
Cheers to more adventures with One Piece!!

It's a thank you letter to the fans who grew up with it, found comfort in it, and still carry those lessons today. You can feel the gratitude in every frame. It’s short, heartfelt, and somehow feels like the anime equivalent of the creators saying, “Thank you for being part of this journey” (╥ ᴗ ╥) ♡〜 One Piece: The Fan Letter reminds you why One Piece means so much to so many people. It reminded me that One Piece isn’t just an anime, it’s a journey that lives inside every fan. It’s less about the Straw Hats themselves and more about the people they’veinspired.

The animation also sets it apart. It strays from One Piece’s usual bold and exaggerated style, trading it for something softer and almost watercolor-like. It gives the short this dreamy, delicate, nostalgic vibe, like a memory you can’t quite let go or like flipping through memories of your own childhood. It feels different, but in the best way.

Thank you, One Piece, for growing up with us. 🥹💌

Masterpiece. Good animation, a whole new stlye of animation,the storyline. It also feels nice to see the one piece world from the perspective of commoners. I love how they were able to incorporate all of the events in one episode (24 minutes). I also like the fact that we get to see the opinions of commoners about the strawhats. I also wish they could use this style of animation for the main series. I assure you that this episode will fill you with joy. Highly recommend especially if you are a one piece fan. Just take it as a way of comforting yourself since wewill be seeing a 6 months hiatus.

Honestly, this episode delivers everything you'd expect from a title like 'Fan Letter' and then some. It’s a heartfelt tribute not just to the characters but to the fanbase itself. The visuals are absolutely stunning, but the animation doesn’t just look good—it actively enhances the storytelling (especially the use of light and shadows, Ishitani is so good at this!!). And while the plot might seem straightforward at first glance, it's packed with subtle nods to long-time fans, making it a deeply rewarding experience for anyone who's followed the journey. It's an absolute must-watch, whether you're a die-hard fan or someone just catching up.

The One Piece fan letter gives viewers a look into the world of One Piece from the perspective of just normal every day citizens rather than that of the Straw Hats like we normally get. While none of the characters have names they also play no vital role in the story as a whole and yet we feel connected to them as fellow fans of the Straw Hats. Megumi Ishitani really outdid herself as the director for this TV special. The animation is beautiful, crisp, and clean. The voice acting for each character really shows the joy and passion they all had working on thisproject. A perfect side story to the adventure that is One Piece.

Truly a letter from a fan to One Piece. There was no need to actually show whatever was written in that letter, it was shown through everything else. Any avid fan of One Piece can agree that this simple spin-off captured the emotional attachment one would have towards One Piece, especially the Straw Hat Pirates. A re-telling of the arcs between the Grand Line and the New World from the perspective those in the background; either watching the events play out in real time, or just coming across a chance meeting. A nice little worldbuilding snippet into what it would be like for those background characters tofeel towards the crew. It was a premise that I wasn't expecting for a spin-off, but they executed it amazingly. It wasn't just a nostalgic feeling, but it was a cinematic experience that might just have you bawling your eyes out.

It wasn't just a letter, it was a love letter for everything One Piece gave to its fans.

My only real "gripe" is that it's nothing overly hype. But I do think that despite that, this is a masterpiece of an episode/special. Yes, it's about people who were affected by the Strawhat crew. And I love that there was a representation of us fans in the episode. It is based on a One Piece novel, but I would say it's more of its own thing than anything as it's far removed from that One Piece Novel. Overall, 10/10 great episode and an addition to the One Piece anime. Also to add, the animation was great. it really fit with what the episode wasgoing for when going through the story of the special/episode.

The One Piece Fan Letter was a perfect way to say a temporary goodbye from the show to us the fans. The story takes place just before fishman island on sabaody archipelago and depicts a young female fan who idolises Nami desperately trying to deliver a letter to her. I view the story itself as we are the fan and we all aspire and idolise the crew, to the fan the crew is everything and without them we wouldnt all have banded together despite our personal situation’s or struggles to watch each episode every week. So just like the story certain characters lives where influenced by the crewdrastically changing who they are and their beliefs. 

And exactly like them we the fans have our own memories and sentimental moments we hold dear to us all thanks to this amazing story.

This special really came across as one big thank you to us and I personally felt emotional seeing the way the crew banded its worlds characters together in unison at the end as fans of the strawhats.

We are those fans and us too have seen them grow into what we have today and will we continue to support and be inspired by the crew.
It will be a long 6 months but me and every other ‘fan’  

we can’t wait for their return!

I stand up and applaud Megumi Ishitani, she is the definition of capturing feelings in animation, simply beautiful. This chapter was totally crazy, all the feelings that it transmits to us, we have nostalgia, emotions, sadness, goosebumps, happiness, among many others. The truth is that part that really drove me totally crazy is how this "little Nami fan" shows how she puts together each "piece of the puzzle" giving rise to the last piece, giving an idea of ​​the meaning and what "ONE PIECE" achieves, the truth is that it was beautiful, THE BEST ANIME CHAPTER I'VE SEEN TO THIS DAY. The story of this chapter isunique, a new perspective to see One Piece and thus understand many things, it's like a fan sees everything that the Muwigaras generate and achieve, the artistic style (animation) was SPECTACULAR, the color palette, the fluidity of how everything combines and thus demonstrates the true essence of ONE PIECE, it's simply beautiful.
In just 20 minutes they showed us such a great development of secondary characters that today in animes with more than 24 chapters they can't achieve and be honest, this is real.
If you've never seen One Piece and you watched this chapter you have two reactions, either you don't like the anime or YOU GET EXCITED WITHOUT HAVING SEEN ONE PIECE BECAUSE THIS IS CRAZY.

One Piece Fan Letter, Like the name suggests is a heartfelt letter to all OP fans across every corner of the world. It’s a true love letter that carries the weight of twenty five years of story, emotion, and adventure. For the millions of people who grew up watching Luffy and his crew, this special episode remind us that One Piece is more than just an anime. It’s a life experience. I'm glad that Megumi Ishitani is receiving the recognition she deserves. If her name sounds familiar, she the one that directed OP episode 1015, one of the series most beautiful episode. She understands OP ina way few directors do, grasping both its grandeur and its intimacy. I hope to be able to see more projects of her, she has proven herself more than capable. 

Going back to the episode, I actually teared up watching this masterpiece. One Piece Fan Letter, capture the essence of OP so well and remind you why this series has been at the top for so long. OP is about the people, about the relationships we build, the promises we make, and the dreams we chase. It’s a soft, nostalgic memory of the first time, I was still a kid and watched Luffy set sail. Even after watching 1000 plus episodes, this special episode made me remember why I fell in love with One piece in the first place. This episode is a gift and a thank you from the creators to its fans. It’s a reminder that we are all part of this journey and that as long as there are seas to sail, the adventure will never end.

extremely over hyped. uh yeah this is just cool animations nothing more really, it has a shallow story but you can't expect much. (no pedo shit which makes it already makes it better anything post time skip has to offer) Positives: it is a very visually pleasing OVA and I think its cool to contextualize the story from an ordinary Jim in the world. Negatives: too short for the story they are trying to give so the story suffers and feels half assed, its tied to the One Piece, the cuts feel too hectic at points to just get some story then they give us along ass nothing burger cuts, adds nothing really to the story.

I'm not a One Piece enjoyer anymore but this was a cool watch

One of the most beautiful pieces of fiction ever created. This episode encapsulates everything that makes the One Piece world beautiful. It displays how incredible the world-building is while also highlighting so many of the elite characters with super sharp animation. The themes covered in this short twenty minutes by the "background" characters on Sabaody go a very long way in contextualizing the influence the Straw Hats have on the One Piece world and the significance of their adventure. I truly believe this project will revolutionize the story and open an entirely different dimension of lore that can enhance the story for years and yearsafter it is completed. Actual peak fiction.

Absolutely cinema! One of the most terrifying works I have ever watched in my life. Everything about it was great, from the drawing to the writing to the characters to everything. Great work. A great episode It truly pushed the boundaries of what I thought was possible in storytelling. The emotional depth combined with breathtaking visuals made every moment unforgettable. I found myself on the edge of my seat, completely immersed in the plot. The creativity and effort behind this work are evident and inspiring. I can't wait to see what comes next and how it continues to elevate average This is the kindof masterpiece that sticks with you long after it's over. Truly a legend among legends

I am a huge one piece fan, and while I'm not as hyped as everyone else is about this, I enjoyed it nontheless. It was interesting to see the world of one piece through the eyes of the marines and civilians, and the power-scaling discussion was legitimately funny. I wasn't rolling on the floor struggling for air or anything, but it made me chuckle. (Sanji will always be my number 1) Oh and the animation...my god the animation. Beautiful, absolutely beautiful. But yeah, I'm not in tears or anything, but I can appreciate all the love and care that went into this.

When I saw this beautiful love letter to One Piece, I was truly speechless. I couldn't believe a movie could capture so much of how I felt about the series. I'm not the biggest One Piece fan, but it touched me deeply in my heartito, Obviously, if it affected me, who isn't that big of a One Piece fan, I wonder how it affected someone who is a huge One Piece fan. Well, I suppose that's what the reviews section and the rating are for (which would explain the very high score). That little girl represents meeee 😭 ESP: ME ENCANTA, SOY ESA, SOY ESA, SOY ESA

One Piece Fan Letter is a high-quality, lovingly crafted production made for all the people across the years who have supported and have been invested in the world of One Piece. The ambitious direction and storyboarding created a solid, consistent foundation that propelled creativity, storytelling, and fan service to new peaks. One notable standout was the use of perspective in both the animation and character writing. Seeing firsthand how the average individual, both from a distance and in the action, lives and breaths was compelling. The Straw Hat Pirates continue to have an effect on others from a variety of different backgrounds, in-universe or not.

Probably one of the greatest One Piece episodes of all time, and I didn’t expect it at all. Just as the title goes, it is a fan-targeted work, and if you ARE a OP fan, you definitely can feel the love and effort the staff put in these 24 minutes. The animation is unique but exquisite, the story is rather short but complete, the music is flawless, and most importantly, the details of the 3d2y settings and the connection between characters are just incredible. Taking another look at the Marineford from the perspective of a “nobody” is such a smart move that reminds me howcomplicated the war was and how the strawhats affect others. Through the watching, I could not help relating to all of them, and the emotions. Thank you God, this one-shot is a perfect love letter to One Piece and One Piece fans.

I'M IN TEARS! One Piece Fan Letter is not just an open letter to all fans of this beautiful and great work that we love so much... this special is the Soul of One Piece! I can't even express how much I cried watching these 24 minutes, I practically didn't blink, nothing distracted me... it was total immersion! I know this is obvious, but MEGUMI ISHITANI is surreal... Transcribing all the sentimentality, passion and hope that the original work conveys through a short 24-minute episode... SURREAL... The passion of every little animation, every subtle and simple camera movement, every cut simply structured in the mosttouching way possible. I could do a critical analysis, citing every single thing that makes this special stand out, mentioning all the things that make it UNIQUE. But, I can't find any other meaning other than LOVE and DEDICATION. THANK YOU SO MUCH, ONE PIECE TEAM!

Truly an exceptional work of art by Megumi Ishitami. Her art style fits one piece so much This show gives us a look in what it's like to live as a mundane person living in the grand line. The harrowing experiences of these people give so much more depth into the world building of one piece (which was already vast). It gives us a deep dive into the aspirations of these people and what led them to be inspired by them. If I were to point out a weakness of the show is that it just doesn't have more, even though the episode leaves without anygaps in the story, it gave me a deep hole in my heart that can only be quenched by more content about the mundane everyday lives of the inhabitants of one piece world. It truly exceeds all expectations, I didn't even think I would ever cry for someone who isn't part of the main cast, and yet here I am sobbing. I wish for more works of art like this please. This show expresses so much emotions in me that I don't think that this review can contain it.

One piece fan letter is a brilliantly directed, animated, and written love letter to the story of one piece. It manages to keep you enthralled with the beautiful animation and soundtrack, and manages to create a strong emotional connection between the audience and the characters. The highlights to me were the parts that focused on the marines, as seeing the marineford war from the perspective of normal navy foot soldiers was enthralling, and the characters we followed during it managed to establish an amazing dynamic in a short amount of time. If you are a fan of one piece, this is a must watch, andeven if you've never seen one piece before, there's still plenty to enjoy here with the amazing animation as well as it being a mostly self-contained story, although you will be missing out on a lot of fun moments if you haven't seen the original series (and potential spoilers).

This is peak. I watched it 10 times still i never felt bored.Well i saw some of the reviews but they don't have any point just haters who never watches one piece.It's animation has a different level aura. Just too good.They showed us how the Marine felt during the greatest war marineford. Their pain, their struggling to alive amongst the powerful people and a letter from a fan 😍.The story is unique like a fan who wants to see their ideal .it's really too real i felt this that it's me who actually trying to give the letter to strawhat.the art style is really super.It's a movie type animation I've seen some of this types of animation and the story overall is too good and also i don't think people will hate it.Just peak 🔥😍

In my opinion this is one of the best one piece episodes ever made. While watching it I felt like this was all real the story seen throughout a normal Mariner's eyes is completely different from what we were used to the scenes were crude it felt like I was watching all of that happen in front of my eyes and throughout all the episode I was on the edge of my seat hoping for the marines to make it out alive. The little girl part was also real I felt like she was like this anime fanbase admiring the straw hats and dreaming about livingan adventure like theirs and I truly felt what she was experiencing.
This episode was truly amazing and not to talk about the animations megumi ischitani is truly one of the best directors out there. So I found this episode outstanding one of the best anime episodes I ever watched.

I don't want to act like someone who thinks that One Piece is perfect, but goddammit, this episode hit all the right spots, from the animation to even the timing of the OST. I must admit that I only started this journey 7 months ago and that I still haven't caught up with the manga or the anime, but those 20 minutes are the definition of why so many people love this series, from the characters to its detailed world. If you are a One Piece fan, do yourself a favor and watch this episode; it's totally worth your time!

One of the greatest episodes of television I've ever seen. You can tell how much the creators of this episode love One Piece. Megumi Ishitani is back again after episode 1015 with another beautifully directed piece. The visuals of this special are incredibly dynamic and every scene is captivatingly full. Similar to epsiode 1015, this special hits you with emotions but it makes sure to demonstrate hope and inspiration. This is not only through the main girl's multiple references to Nami being her hope, but how characters are continually saved by the Straw Hats. One of the best parts of this special is despite noteven knowing the new characters' names, you can feel for them through their shared experiences. This special shows us the "man of the ground" perspective of world shaking events. It's chilling to see how Mihawk and Crocodile fight over top of dead and wounded soldiers without a scratch on them. Of course there are injuries are death in the main series, but seeing things on this smaller scale within one of the largest and most important events in the series is a little staggering. 

I think even if you haven't ever seen an episode of One Piece before, you could enjoy this special. Sure, you won't get the references to the Straw Hats, or understand the context of the events portrayed, but there are enough "show not tell" scenes that are amazing at demonstrating why we as an audience, and small time characters would be fans of this series.

Less than I expected, but it's still good. From the reviews I've seen and the rating it has on MAL, I thought it would be a masterpiece from another world, but that's not exactly what I saw. Don't get me wrong, this OVA is good, but it didn't impress me as much as other people out there. I thought this OVA was very creative in presenting another point of view of the world of One Piece, a point that had never been explored before (at least as far as I can remember), the side of the secondary characters and at the same time another vision ofthe world of One Piece. This OVA explores the perspective of the extras on the main characters, shows how ordinary people react to the main events of the work, a space that I can't imagine being included in this way in the manga or the main anime (because if it were in the main versions of One Piece, people would find it boring, lol). Anyway, I liked the idea they presented here, it's a short and fun episode to pass the time, about the animation style I don't have much to complain about BUT, I found the animation at certain moments quite strange (or bad, so to speak), for example, at some moments it's clear that the lines become very simple to make the movement of the environment more fluid but with that we have some frames and some characters with animation that is not at all "normal", and look, I'm talking about One Piece that has characters that are not at all normal, anyway, Nami also had a terrifying and ugly face at one point.

I conclude that this work is in fact good but it's not the greatest wonder in the world as it has been treated, I liked the idea of ​​the script and I found the animation reasonable since there are some moments where it declines, with that I end my review with a score of 7, I would watch it again for sure.

=================================================================================================================Versão em Português=====================================

Menos do que eu esperava mas ainda sim é algo bom.

Pelas review que vi por ai e pela nota que tem no MAL eu achei que seria uma obra prima de outro mundo mas não foi bem isso que vi, não me entendam errado, essa OVA é boa mas não me impressionou tanto quanto as outras pessoas por ai. Achei que essa OVA foi muito criativa ao por um outro ponto de vista do mundo de One Piece, um ponto que nunca havia sido explorado antes (ao menos até onde minha memoria lembra), o lado dos personagens secundários e ao mesmo tempo uma outra visão do mundo de One Piece. Essa OVA explora a visão dos figurantes sobre os personagens principais, mostra como pessoas comuns reagem aos acontecimentos principais da obra, um espaço que não consigo imaginar sendo encaixado dessa forma no mangá ou no anime principal (até porque se fosse nas versões principais de One Piece o pessoal acharia chato kkk). De toda forma, gostei da ideia que apresentaram aqui, é um episodio curto e divertido de se passar o tempo, sobre o estilo de animação eu não tenho muito a reclamar MAS, achei a animação em certos momentos bem estranha (ou ruim por assim dizer), por exemplo, alguns momentos é nítido que os traços se tornam muito simples pra deixar o movimento do ambiente mais fluidos mas com isso temos alguns frames e alguns personagens com uma animação nem um pouco "normal", e olha que estou falando de One Piece que tem personagens nada normais, enfim, a Nami tambem ficou com um rosto tenebroso de feio em um momento.

Concluo que essa obra é de fato boa mas não é a maior maravilha do mundo como tem sido tratada, gostei da ideia do roteiro e achei a animação razoável visto que tem alguns momentos que ela decai, com isso finalizo minha review com uma nota 7, veria de novo com certeza.

Hands down THE BEST EPISODE this 2024. Even if this is not cannon whatsoever. This episode is just peak. The animation, story, character, in just the span of 23 minutes, you get to love the kid and those marines who fought in the war. You get to see their perspectives, perspective of a normal person. Hope they make more of different perspectives of different characters in the one piece world. I can't express how much I really loved this single episode! It made me feel again why I loved one piece so much! Even without the fighting, and the extreme visual effects. Just the rightdirections and music can make anything a masterpiece. Thank you toei

One Piece Fan Letter is a project that has been begging to be made for a while now. A short spinoff about some relatively inconsequential characters within the One Piece universe and how their lives have been affected by the Straw Hats’ upending the world order feels like a no-brainer in hindsight and fills the same niche as something like Twilight Wings or PokéToon does for the Pokémon franchise. The main protagonist’s unbridled admiration for Nami carries the age-old shounen theme of inspiring the next generation with incredibly moving and uplifting narrative drive, while the pair of Marine brothers placed as foils against Luffy andAce showcases the destructive power of Devil Fruit users and how seemingly miniscule the average soldier is by comparison, and the many cameo appearances from the Straw Hats and other One Piece regulars provide excellent comedic relief to pump you with just enough fan service without distracting from the anime original characters.
The true power of this episode, however, lies in its absolutely impeccable visual presentation. Lavish color choices, flexible yet immediately iconic character designs, intriguing visual symbolism, and jaw-dropping action all come together to craft a nonstop brilliant piece of animation. This is, quite simply, one of the best-looking things I’ve seen the entire year, representing One Piece as a whole perfectly in its creativity and ambition. Truth be told, the only reason it isn’t higher on this list is because I’m not quite as big a One Piece fan as its core base is, and so it didn’t fully move me with the same intensity as the aforementioned Pokémon spinoffs, but the fact that I still gushed about it this much shows how masterfully it executed this idea and how ripe for narrative exploration the world of One Piece is.

As a one piece fan, I'm disappointed. From how much fans were overhyping this I came into it expecting the best episode or something. In reality, it's just a cute little filler special full of fanservice; nothing to elevate the main material. It's nothing special. I couldn't care less about the new characters and their emotional struggles despite how hard and in your face the story tried to make me do so in the span of 24 minutes. Oda is also being weird again with that unfunny forced joke where the young girl tries to flirt with the drunk bar goers and nothing of valuewould've been lost just doing without it.

The visuals also look really cheap at times and I sincerely hope this isn't the direction that new one piece episodes begin taking. The music is forgettable, though it's not something this series was ever known for. I enjoyed the voice acting at least.

I'm not overhyped like most people here but I gotta tell yall, It's a decent filler episode. It's not great, doesn't bring anything new to the table other than fanservice. Actually, it's the first time I see someone portray the fanbase of something so well into an episode, that's pretty fun to see. But you have nothing truly engaging here. In 24 minutes, I couldn't care less about the nami-wannabe or the marine brothers. The greatest part in this episode is indeed the powerscale discussion, that's funny AF cuz it actually escapes from most filler-anime cliches and that's rare to see. As the name sugests,it's a special, it adds nothing to the main story, it only celebrates in some way. If you are unsure whether or not you should watch cuz It's filler, It's worth a try. But is not necessary to the story.

Given how there is only one (negative) review, I've decided to share my thoughts as well and give it a different (more positive) perspective. So, this light novel series is divided into 2 volumes, the first one being 130 pages long and the second one being 230 pages long (around there); and so it is quite a simple and easy read in an afternoon or two. The first volume shows how ace got his devil fruit and how he founded and built his crew with several members being named and becoming somewhat plot relevant albeit only in the novel. This first volume follows Ace and Deuce,who is actually the novel's protagonist and narrator, from their first encounter in the East Blue until Sabaody, and their adventures. Most of the info on volume is new, but there's nothing groundbreaking in terms of importance. Nevertheless it managed to keep me interested. 

The second volume deals with a lot of things that were already shown in the manga/anime, like the Ace/whitebeard relationship, Blackbeard's conflict, Ace's execution et cetera. i do feel however, that the light novel feels more complete in terms of portraying ace's real feelings and emotions than the manga did, though maybe it is because it is all in a written format with no images and it is easier to portray those things.

Overall, If you like One Piece and if you feel curious about this light novel I'd tell you to give it a try. It's an enjoyable read.

Ace’s Story makes Ace’s character and arc in One Piece more whole. It offers lots of untold background and detailed life as a pirate. The first couple of chapters are very descriptive and you can feel the dry heat from the pages. This manner of writing is consistently found throughout the two volumes and makes the read a lot more engaging. An issue I have with these two books are the rehashing of One Piece knowledge we already know. It discusses things we already know well, and does so often. While I don’t mind being reminded of something, the extent of which this author takes itis a bit much.

Besides that, the new stories are compelling enough to override that issue a healthy amount. It’s a sweet tale, and a definite must-read for any Ace fan. Good stuff. 7/10

Completely forgettable. Some guys decided to write a spin off story about Ace's journey/Pirate adventures, or so it seemed.
